description.narrative:
SAFAIDS har ansökt om 75 miljoner kronor för att genomföra sin regionala strategi “Transforming the Policy Environment for Accelerating Access to Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) by adolescents and young people, within an SDGs framework, in southern Africa 2018 – 2020.”
Det övergripande målet med insatsen är att bidra till en mer gynnsam politisk miljö som möjliggör positiva SRHR-resultat bland ungdomar och unga kvinnor i södra Afrika senast 2020. Det föreslagna programmet har fyra strategiska mål.
- Policyutveckling: Stödja utvecklingen av SADC-riktlinjer gällande ungdomar och sexuellt och könsbaserat våld senast 2020,
- Policypåverkan: Påverka SADCs medlemsstater att öka insatserna mot oavsiktliga graviditeter och osäkra aborter bland sexuellt aktiva ungdomar senast 2020,
- Övervakning av socialt ansvar: Stärka kapaciteten hos regionala ungdomsorganisationer och nätverk för ansvarsutkrävande vad gäller tillhandahållandet av SRHR Information och tjänster riktade till ungdomar i södra Afrika senast 2020,
- Evidens och kunskapsutbyte: Förbättra utbytet av modeller, innovationer och strategier för sexuellt och/eller könsbaserad våld (SGBV), oavsiktlig graviditet och osäker abort bland ungdomar senast 2020.
SAfAIDS har varit partner till det regionala SRHR-teamet sedan 2004. SAfAIDs tar emot finansiering från en diversifierad pool av finansiärer som inkluderar Sveriges regionala SRHR-team, HIVOS, Irland, EU, UNAIDS Regional support team och Stop AIDS Now. Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att finansieras fullt ut av Sida.

SAfAIDS has applied for 75 million SEK to implement their regional strategy programme, Transforming the Policy Environment for Accelerating Access to Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) by adolescents and young people, within an SDGs framework, in southern Africa 2018 – 2020.The overall goal of the intervention is to contribute towards a more conducive policy environment that enables positive SRHR outcomes among adolescents and young women, in Southern Africa, by 2020. The proposed programme will realise 4 strategic objectives;- Policy Development: Support the development of Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) Sexual Gender-based Violence (SGBV) Response Guidelines for Adolescents by Member States, by 2020,- Policy Advocacy: Advocate to SADC Member States to scale up prevention of unintended pregnancies and unsafe abortions among sexually active adolescents by 2020,- Social Accountability Monitoring: Strengthen the capacity of regional youth organisations and networks in social accountability monitoring of the delivery of youth-friendly SRH Information and services in Southern Africa, by 2020,- Evidence and Knowledge Sharing: Enhance knowledge sharing of models, innovations and strategies on Sexual Gender Based Violence (SGBV), unintended pregnancies and unsafe abortions among adolescents and social accountability monitoring within the region and across the broader sector by 2020. In regards to the budget, it is assessed that the proposed total budget of 75,000,000 SEK for this invention is sufficient, and reasonable to meet the planned outcomes. The allocated budget for the SAfAIDS six months inception phase is USD1,958,836 (SEK16,249,131). Six per cent (6%) of the inception budget relates to activities for a technical expert report, internal regional 2 day inception meeting, regional partner visit and regional and national sensitization meetings with key stakeholders. 28% of the program activities also relate to costs for arranging a regional rapid assessment on the adolescent Sexual Gender Based Violence (SGBV) related policy environment, organizing a meeting to develop an Assessment Methodology Protocol (AMP), conducting an induction meeting for assessment team, conducting a national meeting to validate the rapid assessment findings, regional meeting to validate the rapid assessment findings, developing a mobile social accountability monitoring application (including tech tools and systems) for SRHR in partnership with Rhodes University, develop a toolkit on social accountability monitoring for youth SRH Services and Technical Consultancy. Two per cent (2%) of the budget has been allocated to monitoring & evaluation and finance compliance and monitoring visits, while six per cent (6%) of the budget has been allocated to capital expenditure. Ten per cent (10%) of the budget relates to administration costs whilst 48% of the planned budget relates to staff costs. The reason for the high staff costs is a result of SAfAIDS not complying with MCP/PLGHA, which has resulted in SAfAIDS losing USAID funding that was contributing to SAfAIDS staff and administration costs of up to 16%. SAfAIDS receives funding from a diversified pool of funders that include Sweden, Hivos, Irish Aid, European Union, UNAIDS Regional, Stop AIDS Now, and USAID. The largest funders are Sweden and USAID who together contributed more than 60% of resources to SAfAIDS.

Transforming Lives is a 3.5 year regional policy and advocacy programme (2018-2022 including a no-cost extension), which seeks to contribute towards a more conducive policy environment that enables positive SRHR outcomes among adolescents and young people in Southern Africa. The programme seeks to work at the regional level to influence policy in three thematic SRHR spheres of sexual gender-based violence, adolescent pregnancy and unsafe abortion with links to maternal mortality and access to youth friendly SRHR information and services. The programme will contribute directly to SDG 3 on Good Health and Well-being and SDG 5 on Gender Equality, and make linkages to targets under SDGs 10 and 16.
The programme goal is to contribute towards a more conducive policy environment that enables positive SRHR outcomes among adolescents and young women in Southern Africa. The Programmes Strategic Objectives (SOs) are:
Strategic Objective 1 (SO1): Support the development of SADC Sexual Gender-based Violence Response Guidelines for Adolescents and Young People by Member States, by 2022.
Strategic Objective 2 (SO2): Advocate to SADC Member States to scale up Prevention of Early and Unintended Pregnancies and Unsafe Abortions among Sexually Active Adolescents, by 2022.
Strategic Objective 3 (SO3): Strengthen the Capacity of Regional Youth Organisations and Networks in Social Accountability Monitoring of the delivery of Youth-friendly SRH Information and Services in southern Africa, by 2022.
Strategic Objective 4 (SO4): Enhance knowledge sharing of models, innovations and strategies on SGBV, Early and Unintended Pregnancies (EUP) and Unsafe Abortions among Adolescents and Young People and SAM for SRHR within the region and across the broader sector, by 2022.

description.narrative:
It should be noted that a number of the results that are reported by SAfAIDS are from activities that are in conjunction with other organisations such as the UN, SADC, SADC PF and other CSOs. In some cases these organisations also receive direct funding from Sida.
Strategic Objective 1 (SO1): Support the development of SADC Sexual Gender-based Violence Response Guidelines for Adolescents and Young People by Member States, by 2022.
- Six virtual roundtables on SGBV during a crisis wee held with 91 delegates from Ministries of Gender/Womens Affairs, Health, Education, Justice; and Members of Parliament, media practitioners, traditional and religious leaders from the 16 SADC Member States. Of the 91 delegates, 56 responded to a google feedback form and indicated clear actions and commitments they would take to address SGBV in their respective countries. SAfAIDS reported that the Roundtables kept the momentum in the SGBV policy advocacy narrative among policy-makers whose attention had shifted more towards the pandemic response.
- In widening and strengthening regional economic community scope for collaboration and solidarity on the SGBV agenda, SAfAIDS commenced engagements with the COMESA Secretariats Gender and Social Affairs Division. SAfAIDS was invited to participate in the COMESA Technical Committee Meeting on Gender and Womens Affairs and the Gender Ministers Meeting in March 2021 and relations plan to be deepened during 2022.
- Three virtual engagements were held with the SADC Secretariat Gender Unit on moving forward the Regional Guidelines on SGBV Response among Adolescents and Young People.
- Other: The SADC-PF CSO Desks continued to be hosted by SAfAIDS, for a second year running, and produced Issues 1 and 2 of the SADC-PF & CSO Linking: Quarterly NewsFlash, a publication which seeks to inform and share, as well as motivate and strengthen the interactions of the SADC-PF, Parliamentarians, Parliament as an institution, with CSOs in the SADC region on matters related to SRHR, HIV, gender equality, womens empowerment, youth development, Universal Health Coverage (UHC), and other regional sustainable development matters.
Strategic Objective 2 (SO2): Advocate to SADC Member States to scale up Prevention of Early and Unintended Pregnancies and Unsafe Abortions among Sexually Active Adolescents, by 2022.
- Despite challenges with COVID-19 which shifted focus of Ministers of Health to the pandemic response, SAfAIDS held three virtual Regional Policy Advocacy Dialogues with the Regional Coalition of Safe Abortion Champions & Allies (54 participants) to generate recommendations and a position for a Regional Roadmap on addressing unsafe abortion among AGYW in the SADC region.
- The regional campaign to end unsafe abortions among AGYW through policy advocacy - My Choice, Our Choice (MCOC) - continued. During the reporting period, the campaigns digital products included 7 Spotlight Issues, 23 Flash-Messages and Clips, 9 Radio Jingles, 5-Episode audio-visual studio recordings, 3 Animation Videos in the 3 official SADC languages, and advocacy materials (with messaging on the impact of restrictive laws on access to safe abortion by AGYW). 438,013 people were reached via social media alone in the SADC region, and combined with mass media and direct reach the number was approximately 1.6 million people.
- SAfAIDS launched the My Choice, Our Choice special edition 5-Episode series Access to Safe Abortion is a Human Rights & Saving Lives Matter! on The Naked Truth Show, reaching 5,600 people on social media.
- Examples of country-specific activities: Lesotho (a National Caucus held with SADC PF on safe abortion), Zimbabwe (a caucus meeting for CSO partners, government officials and parliamentarians working on the review of the Termination of Pregnancy Act in Zimbabwe), South Africa (disseminating key messages advocating for removal of policy restrictions particularly the Clause on Conscientious Objection limiting Adolescent Girls and Young Women's access to safe abortion services and information).
- SAfAIDS in collaboration with UNFPA ESARO, WHO, African Population and Health Research Centre (APRHC), Ipas and Guttmacher Institute hosted a regional policy advocacy dialogue on reducing maternal mortality, unsafe abortion and increasing access to contraceptives in June 2021. This formed part of the 2gether4SRHR initiative. The dialogue was attended by 57 participants from CSOs, UN agencies, SRHR advocates and development partners, working in maternal health, unsafe abortion, family planning, as well as networks of key populations, women, youth, PLHIV and people with disabilities. SAfAIDS reported that the policy dialogue facilitated wider reach of advocacy on safe abortion and prevention of EUP and identified opportunities for the coming period to advance SDG targets of reducing maternal mortality, including deaths relating to unsafe abortion and to achieve universal access to family planning.
- SAfAIDS hosted virtual Regional Sectoral Dialogues on Prevention of Pregnancies and Unsafe Abortion in SADC reaching 38 PRTHJ (political, religious, traditional, health and justice) Leaders from 11 SADC member States and 30 Members of Parliament from 12 SADC countries. The Dialogues explored the extent of unsafe abortion, its impact on AGYWs well-being, development, morbidity and mortality in the region; and its links to EUP and SGBV. The Dialogues aimed to mobilise and motivate policy makers towards inputting into the Year 2 generated draft Regional Roadmap on Ending Unsafe Abortions among AGYW; and systematically address the safe abortion agenda in SADC.
Strategic Objective 3 (SO3): Strengthen the Capacity of Regional Youth Organisations and Networks in Social Accountability Monitoring of the delivery of Youth-friendly SRH Information and Services in southern Africa, by 2022.
SO3 The key focus in Year 3 was on up-scaling the SAM4SRHR model and building sustainability, sharing lessons, and taking SAM4SRHR capabilities to scale with wider pool of young people.
- 16 SAM4SRHR sustainability meetings were held in the eight pilot country intervention sites with representatives from youth-led CSOs, Ministers of Health and community representatives which led to the development of 8 Country Sustainability plans in order to scale-up the initiative for monitoring SRH services.
- SAFAIDS also supported clinic-based SAM4SRHR Youth Champions to mobilize access SRH services and report service challenges using MobiSAfAIDS. 21,339 adolescents and young people (against a target of 29,294) have registered on the MobiSAfAIDS App (COVID-19 stalled registration) and 2494 SRHR issues have been reported, of which 887 are open, 634 have been resolved, 909 closed. 55% of issues were on HIV testing and services. In 2020-2021, 582 issues were raised and 467 (80%) have been resolved by service providers. This activity strengthened capacity of regional youth organisations and networks in social accountability monitoring (SAM) of delivery of AYSRH information and services.
- SAfAIDS continued its partnership with six-youth led CSOs. Through activity-related financial support, the CSOs implemented pilot activities that included mobilization of adolescents and young people, referrals to the local health facility, information dissemination on SRHR, and engaging in advocacy actions. They engaged Clinic-based SAM4SRHR Youth Champions whose role was/is to mobilize adolescents and young people, support their access to HIV and SRH services and report health service delivery challenges via the MobiSAfAIDS Application.
- 114 SAfAIDS Youth SAM4SRHR Champions from 8 pilots sites participated in virtual dialogues using evidence generated through the MobiSAfAIDS app to influence advocacy actions, and though engagement they have increased knowledge about SRHR issues and advocacy skills. A Youth Advocacy and Accountability Alliance (YAAA!) was created and 18 young advocates from the eight countries were identified to be part of YAAA!
Strategic Objective 4 (SO4): Enhance knowledge sharing of models, innovations and strategies on SGBV, EUP and Unsafe Abortions among Adolescents and Young People and SAM for SRHR within the region and across the broader sector, by 2022.
- 7 of the 12 youth-led CSO monitoring and mentoring network meetings took place in each country to facilitate learning and knowledge sharing, ensure quality in delivery and reporting. In addition, an E-learning course on SAM4SRHR for adolescents and young people was developed in order to increase the number of informed young voices in SRHR accountability advocacy. Three trainings were held, with 42 graduates in total during the year.
- 4 position papers targeting decision makers were also developed during the reporting period, focused on the thematic areas SGBV, EUP, unsafe abortion and social accountability for improving the SRHR policy environment.
- 30 virtual chat webinars were held in 6 countries focused on catalyze action towards accelerated, innovative and sustainable local HIV and TB responses.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
